titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dori Laub Interviews of Holocaust Survivors
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham and Christine Connolly

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:46

did.unittitle: Dori Laub interviews of Holocaust survivors

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

langmaterial.language: The material is in English, Romanian, French, Greek, German, Hebrew, Hungarian, Polish, and Czech.

did.abstract: The collection consists of video recordings and transcripts of interviews conducted with Holocaust survivors by Dori Laub, psychoanalyst and psychiatrist, Holocaust survivor, and co-founder of the Fortunoff Video Archive of Holocaust Testimonies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of interviews conducted by Dr. Dori Laub, of Holocaust survivors who were psychiatric patients at the Beer Yaakov Hospital in Israel. Included are video recordings of each interview in the native language of each interviewee, a one-page index of interviews, and transcriptions in English for most of the interviews. Some of the interviews were recorded using both PAL and NTSC standards.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dori Laub was born in Czernowitz, Romania, in 1937. A survivor of the Nazi Holocaust, Laub emigrated to Israel in 1950 where he attended medical school. Dr. Laub became a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, emigrated to the United States, and settled in New Haven, Connecticut, where he was an affiliate of Yale New Haven Hospital. Beginning in 1979, Dr. Laub collaborated with Laurel Vlock to videotape Holocaust survivor testimony, which led to the founding of the Holocaust Survivors Film Project and subsequently the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimonies. Laub died on June 23, 2018, in Woodbridge, Connecticut.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the interviewees of this collection.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy of non-commercially produced items for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dori Laub Interviews of Holocaust Survivors (MS 1986). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.
